1. Add motion blur effect in post process pass
2. Add class "InputHub" to interchange input messages to registered listeners
3. Add class "Timer" to keep elapsed time between frames
4. Move moving & rotation logic into class "Character"
5. Since mouse position sampling interval is pretty random which leads to unstable motion blur, I add some extra code to produce interploated smooth values between 2 samples
Refactor
hehe

Since "width = 2 * near * asp * tan(fov/2)" and "height = 2 * near * tan(fov/2)"
We have "near / (width / 2) = 1 / (asp * tan(fov/2))" and "near / (height / 2) = 1 / tan(fov/2)"
My projection matrix was wrong
Output elapsed time per frame instead of frame count per second

Separate horizontal ssao blur from shading pass, since it's using full screen space blur instead of ssao window size. Therefore performance cost scales according to window size, which is not what I want.

The visual of ssao isn't as good as I expect, probably due to low sample rate per pixel

Big refactor:
1. Add multiple pass classes manage specific render pass
2. Render pass(upper level) is in charge of its frame buffer
3. Change everything accordingly

The render pass pipeline in my mind is something like this:
1. GBuffer generation(Running)
2. SSAO, ShadowMap
3. Deferred shading(Running)
4. PostProcessing(Might divide into multiple passes)

What I'm going to do
1. I didn't fill all render passes right now, which is what Im gonna do.
2. I need to refactor so that color & depth stencil textures are managed in one place and not redundant
Add an interface to acquire color targets
Add interface to acquire attachment information
Add interfaces to acquire targets out of a frame buffer

1. Change gbuffer layout, using full normal since encoding cannot be blended correctly. (There's a way mentioned in Frostbite's document that only 20bits is enough for normal, maybe investigate that later)
2. Add pbr shader into deferred shading fragment shader

1. Add a new out variable in screen_quad vertex shader "OutViewRay".
    This variable is a world space ray shooting from world space camera position to world space screen quad vertex
2. Add gbuffer unpack function in shader "pbr_deferred_shading.frag".
3. Add position reconstruction function in shader "pbr_deferred_shading.frag".

World space position reconstruction works as below:
1). We first acqurie linear space depth value from depth buffer
2). We use this depth as distance from surface to camera
3). Then world space can be rebuilt by dist * viewRay + cameraPosition
Add view coord system matrix and camera near far parameter
Add eye space screen size and inverted eye spacescreen size
Add camera direction in per frame uniforms

Refactor:

Remove validation layer warnings, those which produced by incompatible between vertex buffer info and draw calls

1. Rename OnPassStart & OnPassEnd to BeforeRenderPass & AfterRenderPass, and give them a command buffer
2. BeforeRenderPass and AfterRenderPasswere invoked literally before render pass and after render pass
3. Add another interface AttachResourceBarriers in Material, and it'll be automatically invoked before the beginning of a render pass
3. SSAO material overrides AttachResourceBarriers to ensure gbuffer0(where normal is) is finished rendering and the data will be available during SSAO pass's fragment stage
Render work manager is now managing render works instead of vulkan global
Character moving should be in front of buffer synching
Add material buffer sync function for render work manager

============NOTE==============
Finally I've found the root of the flickering bug:
Per object uniform matrix was updated sometimes event before per frame uniform matrix, which introduced this phenomena.
This works like some objects were using information of last frame, while others using were from this frame

Refactor:
Try to move material init into specific material class, except forward, since it's kind of generic.
Class "Material" is a data driven class, theoractically I coud just do everything in there.
However, generic means complexity. I have to add a good bunch of code inside just in order to make it work for everyone.
I chose a different way, by making some specific material classes and hide specific logic there, I could keep things simple.
I don't wanna make everything complicated like an engine, it's only a code lab project
